Meta.ShortDescription: Artery wall thickens as a result of invasion and accumulation of WBCs and proliferation of intimal-smooth-muscle cell creating an atheromatous (fibrofatt) plaque.

Symptoms.Symptom: Asymptomatic for decades because arteries enlarge at plaque locations, thus there is no affect on blood flow.
Even most plaque ruptures do not produce symptoms until sufficient narrowing or closure of an artery occurs.
Marked narrowing can produce chest pain of angine, shortness of breath, sweating, nausea, dizziness, palpitations.

Causes.Cause: The artherosclerotic process is not fully understood
Initiated by an inflammatory process in the endothelial cells of the blood cell associated with retained low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles.

RiskFactors.RiskFactor: Unhealthy patterns of serum proteins carrying fats and cholesterol

Diagnostics.Diagnostic: Blood serum levels of HbA1c, hs-CRP, and homocysteine

Treatments.Treatment: Anticoagulants like warfarin may actually promote arterial calcification in the long term, despite reducing clot formation in the short term.
